title-group.article-title: Essential Factors for the Development of a Residency Global Health Track

article-meta.aff: 1University of Minnesota Medical School, Minneapolis, Minnesota, MN, USA
2Medical College of Wisconsin, Milwaukee, Wisconsin, WI, USA
3University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health, Madison, Wisconsin, WI, USA

author-notes.corresp: Ann M. Campagna, Department of Pediatrics, University of Minnesota Medical School, East Building, M649, 2450 Riverside Avenue, Minneapolis, MN 55454, USA Email: campa024@umn.edu

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: There is increasing awareness of the importance of global health (GH) residency education but little guidance on what departmental, financial, and human resource support is required to develop a GH track. The authors aimed to identify essential factors and major obstacles to the development of a GH track.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A survey assessing curriculum, support, and factors considered essential to or obstacles to successful development of a GH track was sent to 24 GH education directors within pediatric residencies.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In all, 19 programs (79%) completed the survey, and 6 factors were identified as essential for developing and sustaining a GH track by ≥95% of all GH education directors: supportive residency program director, resident commitment, supportive department chair, protected resident elective time, dedicated budget, and GH faculty with protected time.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Residency programs aiming to start a GH track should start by assessing the availability and sustainability of these identified essential factors within their program.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Over the past few decades, there has been increased interest in global health (GH) training, both at the medical student and resident levels.1-6 Residents indicate that the experience of GH electives is a useful part of their training.1,7,8 Many medical students enter residency with prior GH elective experience. This has increased dramatically over the past 30 years from 6% in 1980 to 30.5% in 2011.9 Increased interest and opportunities have led to higher training expectations, including goals to complete residency with adequate knowledge of tropical medicine and a formation of cultural humility when caring for immigrant and refugee populations.1 Earlier articles have suggested guidelines for creating a useful international elective10-12 and described the development of GH training programs,13-17 but there has been no assessment to date of what factors were deemed essential for the development of a GH track by track directors. Prior studies on GH track development have emphasized the need for resident preparation, mentorship, and funding sources, but these have largely been single-institution studies. With the increase in GH training in pediatric residencies,3 there is now an opportunity to learn from GH track directors which factors have been crucial to the development of a successful and sustainable pediatric GH track and which factors have been obstacles to the development of a track. Such experience-based information would be highly valuable for programs wishing to start a GH track. We conducted a survey of directors of pediatric residency GH training programs in the United States and categorized them into 2 groups based on the formality of their education structure (track vs nontrack). They were asked to outline the characteristics and components of their GH training programs and discern which factors they deemed essential to the development of a GH track.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Our study focused on pediatric residency programs with formalized GH tracks or nontrack structured educational programs. Nontrack educational programs had preelective GH training such as curriculum, workshops, seminars, or other formal preparation in addition to an international elective. To identify these programs, we used 2 methods. First, we surveyed the leadership of the major national organizations, including the American Academy of Pediatrics Section on International Child Health, Academic Pediatric Association International Health Special Interest Group, and Association of Pediatric Program Directors. Second, in the e-mail containing the survey link, we asked the GH education directors identified by these surveys to note any additional programs they were aware of that were potentially missed by the national organizations. Through these methods, we identified 24 US pediatric residency programs that included a formal GH track or nontrack GH education as a part of their pediatric residency. The time from initial notification of national organizations to the last completed survey was October 2010 to February 2011.

We then e-mailed an online survey to the 24 GH education directors. Two subsequent follow-up e-mails were sent along with a final attempt to contact nonresponders with a phone call or personal e-mail. The survey contained questions on components of the GH education program, including questions about factors considered essential to a GH track and the factors that had been or were currently obstacles to the development of a GH track. The authors listed factors that from experience and previously published guidelines18 they thought might be essential (10) or obstacles (14) to the development of a GH track. In addition, for both essential factors and obstacles, the education directors were asked to write in any factors that they felt were important that were not listed. Education directors rated their agreement for essential factors and obstacles according to a 5-point Likert scale (strongly agree, agree, neutral, disagree, strongly disagree).

Programs were asked if they had a formal GH track, as defined by the criteria listed in Table 1. To be identified as a track, all 4 criteria had to be met. These track criteria were formed on the basis of consensus opinion among the authors, all of whom are involved in residency GH education. The complete survey questionnaire is provided in Supplemental Appendix A (Supplementary Tables for this article is available on the Clinical Pediatrics website at http://clp.sagepub.com/supplemental.) Nontrack programs answered questions 5 to 9, and track programs answered questions 10 to 23 (including additional questions concerning when the track started, financial support for residents, and protected faculty time for GH education). All programs provided demographic information and answered questions 24 and 25.

caption.p: Criteria Defining a Residency Global Health Track

tr.td: 1. A structured curriculum in global health for all residents in the track (lectures, seminars, and interactive sessions that cover essential information on GH), provided over a 1- to 3-year period
2. An established site in at least 1 resource-limited country where residents can do an elective
3. A preelective orientation to prepare residents for the elective experience
4. A postelective debriefing session with a GH mentor

sec.p: All analyses involving program characteristics, essential factors, and obstacles between track and nontrack responses were done using Fisher’s exact test, and P values <.05 were considered statistically significant. Characteristics specific to only track programs were evaluated with medians and ranges. This project was reviewed by the University of Minnesota Institutional Review Board and declared “exempt.”

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Institutional participants who completed surveys are presented in Table 2. A total of 20 programs responded to the survey, which is a response rate of 83%. One responding institution, Baylor College of Medicine, did not complete the survey because the program there is structured differently than all others, with residents in the track completing an additional year of residency in an international site. The survey completion rate was 19 of 24 programs (79%).

caption.p: Institutional Participants in the Global Health Education Survey

tr.td: Wayne State University School of Medicine
University of Cincinnati College of Medicine
University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health
University of California San Francisco School of Medicine
University of Utah School of Medicine
Feinberg School of Medicine, Northwestern University
George Washington University School of Medicine and Health Sciences
University of South Carolina School of Medicine
University of Washington School of Medicine

sec.title: Factors Considered Essential for the Successful and Sustainable Development of a GH Track
sec.p: More than 75% of GH education directors agreed or strongly agreed that each of the 10 factors listed was essential to a GH track (Table 3); 95% of GH education directors agreed or strongly agreed that the following 6 factors were most essential to a GH track: a supportive residency director, resident commitment, a supportive department chair, protected resident time for electives, a dedicated budget, and committed GH faculty with protected time. Also, 3 other factors were considered essential by ≥90% of GH education directors: protected resident time for GH educational activities (in addition to electives), strong collaboration with at least 1 international site, and having a GH administrator.

caption.p: Factors Considered to Be Essential Elements of a Formal Global Health Track, by Track (n = 11) and Nontrack (n = 8) Global Health Education Directorsa

tr.td: Protected resident time for international electives
Strong collaboration with at least 1 international site
Committed global health faculty with protected time
Protected resident time for global health educational activities
Faculty with global health research projects

fn.label: a
fn.p: All P values ≥.05 by Fisher’s exact test comparing track versus nontrack within suggested factors and Likert scale classification. Additional write-in responses from global health track directors included (n = 1 for all except where noted) dedication/mentorship of faculty (n = 3), support of head of Graduate Medical Education/ability to have residents paid during rotations (n = 2), objectives and competencies, preknowledge and postknowledge tests, evaluations, clear outline of required and optional components of the track for the residents, mentor support, lecturer support, and residents in a central location.

sec.p: When we considered the results of only the 11 programs with GH tracks, there was unanimous (100%) agreement that 5 of the 6 factors noted above were essential, and 90% agreed on the sixth factor (support of department chair). At the higher threshold of strong agreement, 2 factors were considered as essential by >90% of track directors: residency director support and resident commitment.

sec.title: Factors That Had Been or Were Currently Obstacles to the Development of a GH Track
sec.p: The survey also asked GH education directors about factors that had been or were currently obstacles to their institution’s development of a GH track. This question focused on issues specific to a director’s experience in developing or attempting to develop a track at his or her own institution, in contrast to the prior question, which related to factors that he or she considered essential to the development of a formal GH track at any institution. More varied responses were seen in answers to obstacles actually experienced as opposed to factors deemed essential (Table 4). Two factors had been or were currently obstacles to the development of a GH track at >80% of all institutions: lack of overall track funding and lack of funding for track faculty. Two additional factors were noted to have been or to currently be obstacles at ≥60% of institutions: lack of sufficient protected time for faculty and lack of administrative support. A smaller proportion of track directors, as opposed to nontrack education directors, agreed that each of these factors was or had been an obstacle, but none of the differences was statistically significant (eg, lack of overall funding, 82% vs 86%, P = .99; lack of faculty funding 82% vs 100%, P = .5; lack of protected faculty time 55% vs 100%, P = .5; and lack of administrative support, 60% vs 86%, P = .34).

caption.p: Factors That Had Been or Were Currently Obstacles to the Development of a Global Health Track by Track (n = 11) and Nontrack (n = 7)a Global Health Education Directorsb

tr.td: Lack of funding for protected FTE
Lack of sufficient protected time for faculty
Lack of resident time for global health curriculumc
Resident salaries are unfunded while abroad
Lack of international elective partner site options
Lack of malpractice coverage for international medical work
Lack of disability coverage for residents working abroad

fn.label: a
fn.p: One responder did not complete obstacles section; thus, n = 7 for this section.

fn.label: b
fn.p: All P values ≥.05 by Fisher’s exact test comparing track versus nontrack within suggested factors and Likert scale classification. Additional response included access to the global health track components (required elements and competencies).

fn.label: c
fn.p: One track responder did not complete select obstacle questions; thus, n = 10 for indicated obstacle factors.

sec.title: Components of GH Track or Nontrack Education Programs
sec.p: Required and optional components of the GH education programs are listed in Supplemental Table 1. As compared with nontrack education programs, programs with GH tracks were significantly more likely to offer a local GH elective (100% vs 25%, P = .001) and to offer a course in clinical tropical medicine and traveler’s health certified by the American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene (ASTMH; 45% vs 0%, P = .04). Lecture topics offered by track and nontrack programs are listed in Supplemental Table 2. Track programs were significantly more likely to offer education in some topics that were not disease specific, including cross-cultural health care, maternal health, and poverty and development. The average number of lectures per year was 23 for tracks and 20 for nontracks. Requirements for resident participation in an international elective are listed in Supplemental Table 3.

Track-specific characteristics are listed in Table 5. Most tracks (75%) provided financial support for international electives, and all (100%) had protected faculty time for GH education; but a minority (45%) had a dedicated budget for the track (Table 5). Three tracks had 2 faculty with protected time (median 10% [10%-25%] protected time for the second faculty member). In all, 55% of tracks had administrative staff support, as compared with 25% of nontrack programs (P = .35).

tr.td: Residents match via the National Resident Matching Program
Protected faculty time for global health education
Number of residents in track for all years
Number of residents accepted into track each year

fn.label: c
fn.p: Median percentage of protected time for 1 faculty.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: With the increased demand for GH training opportunities during residency, many programs are developing or enhancing GH programs, including GH tracks. Studies of GH training in residency have assessed curriculum and training,11,19-26 medical knowledge,21,27,28 international elective experience,1,7,8,29 resident characteristics,30-33 and program characteristics.2 Empirical guidelines have been suggested by the Global Heath Education Consortium (GHEC)18 on how to develop a GH program; however, there remains a dearth of evidence-based information on what is required for successful development of a GH training program or track within a residency, perhaps because official training programs or tracks in GH are relatively new in most residencies. In the present study, education directors of successful GH tracks in pediatric residencies and those who led nontrack education programs were asked which factors they considered essential in the development of a GH track. These data thus provide a first assessment of essential factors for successful development of a GH track using data from the most valid source: the directors of GH tracks. There has been no prior delineation or assessment of the factors most commonly agreed on in the literature, and other factors that might be considered equally important (eg, a GH administrator and faculty with GH research projects) did not reach this almost unanimous consensus. Some of the identified essential components and potential obstacles (ie. institutional support, collaboration with international sites, protected time for education, and legal/monetary concerns)are consistent with the guidelines for the development of GH programs suggested by the GHEC.18 The current study provides an evidence base for these guidelines; adds a focused look into these broader categories, such as focusing on an administrator specific to GH; and addresses the additional issues of protected time and funding for faculty and overall program budgets. As interest in GH training increases and an increasing number of residencies aim to include GH training in their educational mandate, a careful assessment of how available and sustainable the factors deemed essential are within their program will allow them to make more informed decisions on track or education program development.

Some of the essential factors outlined may seem self-evident, but they have not previously been published or articulated and are easy to miss in the enthusiasm of setting up a GH training program within a residency. It was important to survey both formalized tracks as well as nontrack education programs because many of those without tracks aim to create a track, and it was important to learn what obstacles these programs currently face. For example, support of the residency director and department chair are intuitively important for any program within a residency, yet the authors are aware of GH initiatives within residencies that have operated without specific support by either. These initiatives may provide admirable results for the limited number of residents that pursue them, but they are often hampered by a lack of adequate training or preparation for the residents and a lack of sustainability because they generally depend on a single faculty member. Recent working group recommendations from the Federation of Pediatric Organizations emphasize the need for a core curriculum and other training initiatives2,3 that are available only through an organized training program. With the recent call for GH training for all residents,11 we concur that GH training should be formalized and integrated into residency programs, as is training for any other area of medicine. Such integration can only occur with buy-in from department chairs and residency directors.

Other factors deemed essential may be less immediately intuitive. A number of residency programs struggle with attempts to provide international electives when there is no guarantee for protected time for such electives. Without this guarantee, planning and pursuit of international electives will remain haphazard and lack academic rigor. If needs assessments of resident interest are not done prior to launching a program, it may lead to a program with a defined structure but lack of participation. Collaboration with at least 1 low-income country partner site is clearly important because there is no substitute to learning on-site, and partnerships between universities or departments may allow smaller departments to leverage the established relationships developed by larger departments.18,29 However, defining a collaborative approach with the partner site, as opposed to a “medical tourism” approach, is critical to a successful long-term relationship that benefits both the partner site and the visiting residents.

Education directors identified lack of overall funding for GH training and lack of funding for protected faculty time for the training as the 2 major obstacles to integration of GH training into their residency programs. Several articles have begun to stress the importance of adequate funding for GH education.34,35 Although many faculty donate time, funding, and supplies to their GH efforts, GH training does not differ from any other academic training: it also requires protected time and funding for adequate curriculum and program development. All 11 programs with GH tracks had faculty with funding for protected time for track education work. This appears to have been a key element that affected their program’s ability to develop a track from a previous nontrack educational format. Two other factors had been or were currently obstacles to the development of a GH track in >60% of GH education programs: lack of protected faculty time and lack of administrative support. Based on these data, an early emphasis on adequate overall track funding, provision of funding for protected faculty time, and provision of administrative support may be particularly important in the successful development of a GH track. We have not identified consistent or obvious methods of funding that would work across residency programs, but within our programs, data on the importance of GH education in attracting the best residents to the program has been important in sustaining departmental funding for this initiative.

The authors defined a track based on considerations of the minimum requirements for a structured training program in GH. They are not aware of any other formal definition for a track. The criteria provided may be considered a starting point for a track definition. Those GH education programs that fit the track definition offered more education options, such as a local GH elective and an ASTMH-certified course in travel and tropical medicine. The differences, and the ability to build a formal track, may relate to differences in institutional support (eg, administrative support).Track programs were also able to offer education on a greater breadth of topics, including non–disease-focused topics. This could be secondary to the broader expertise available at a program able to support a formal GH track and the faculty on-site and available to deliver the identified lectures. All the lecture topics listed overlap with the suggested competency goals suggested by GHEC.18 Many of the non–disease-focused topics fulfill the American College of Graduate Medical Education competencies of practice-based learning and improvement, professionalism, and systems-based practice, which are the more difficult competencies to assess and essential to the development of a GH resident.

The present study chose to list possible essential elements and obstacles and then leave space for open entry of factors not listed. The approach was validated by agreement or strong agreement of education directors with many of the factors listed. It is possible that some of the write-in factors would also have elicited strong agreement, and it is important to note these in Tables 3 and 4. Some of the open entry responses may have been specific to program size and/or resources. A follow-up qualitative study could address and uncover further experiences in the development of a GH track. The query of national pediatric organizations was considered the best method of obtaining information about pediatric GH education programs, but it is possible that some GH programs were missed with this approach. There are many programs with varying degrees of GH education that were not included in the study because we chose to focus on those with a structured GH educational curriculum. This was consistent with the intent of our study to assess structured programs in GH education, as opposed to all residency programs offering international electives; so our study reflects the essential components and obstacles identified by such programs and does not reflect the experience of all residency programs providing international electives. As GH becomes better defined as a discipline, we hope that education in this area will move toward structured and competency-based programs in all residencies as in other major areas of pediatric education.

Looking forward, one way to extend faculty expertise and programmatic support across institutions may be the formation of regional consortia. The authors of the present study helped to found the Midwest Global Health Education Consortium, which is now in its second year of building a network of shared educational resources, experiences, faculty, and international sites among several training programs. A similar model in other regions around the country may allow for increased success with program development.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The present study identified 6 factors that ≥95% of GH education directors agreed were essential to the development of a GH track and 4 factors that more than half of GH education directors agreed had been or currently were an obstacle to the development of a GH track at their institution. As an increasing number of residencies aim to include a GH training in their educational mandate, a careful assessment of the availability and sustainability of the essential factors and of the presence of the related identified obstacles within their program will allow them to make informed decisions on track or program development.

sec.title: Essential Requirements for Global Health Track Survey
sec.p: For the purpose of this survey, a track is defined as a global health education program that has:

list-item.p: 1) A structured curriculum in global health for all residents in the track (lectures, seminars, interactive sessions that cover essential information on global health), provided over a 1-3 year period
2) An established site in at least one resource-limited country where residents can do an elective
3) A pre-elective orientation to prepare residents for the elective experience
4) A post-elective debriefing session with a global health mentor.
